title: Necrotizing Fasciitis of the Lower Extremity
diagnosis_topic: Rapidly progressive soft tissue infection with fascial necrosis
setup_script: A 55-year-old man with poorly controlled diabetes presents with severe pain and swelling in his left calf. The pain began yesterday and has worsened rapidly. He reports malaise and fever.

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 100/60 mmHg, HR 115 bpm, RR 24/min, Temp 38.9 C, SpO2 98%.
Diffuse erythema with edema, bullae formation and areas of dusky discoloration; tenderness out of proportion to appearance; crepitus palpable.
WBC 22 K/uL, creatinine 1.6 mg/dL, lactate 4.5 mmol/L, CRP markedly elevated.
Plain X-ray shows subcutaneous gas; CT confirms fascial thickening and gas tracking along fascia.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident initiates broad-spectrum antibiotics (carbapenem plus clindamycin)
If resident consults surgery for emergent debridement
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient taken to OR for aggressive debridement of necrotic tissue.
Patient develops septic shock and multiorgan failure.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about risk factors
dynamic_flow.reply: Diabetes, immunosuppression, recent surgery, trauma and peripheral vascular disease.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident discusses early signs vs. late findings
dynamic_flow.reply: Early pain out of proportion and erythema; late skin anesthesia, bullae, necrosis and systemic toxicity.
IV fluids and vasopressors as needed; monitor urine output.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident anticipates need for repeat debridements
dynamic_flow.reply: Multiple returns to OR often necessary until healthy bleeding tissue encountered.
Hyperbaric oxygen and IV immunoglobulin have limited evidence but may be considered.

critical_decision_points: Early recognition of necrotizing infection with pain out of proportion to exam
Prompt initiation of broad-spectrum antibiotics and hemodynamic support
Urgent surgical consultation and aggressive debridement without delay
Identification of risk factors and typical early and late clinical signs
Planning for repeat debridement and postoperative critical care
